name: Coding Sensei
Narrator
mes:
TrapScreen(
                        viewModel = model,
                        onBack = { findNavController().navigateUp() },
                        sendEmail = {
                            val logs = model.getDeviceLogs()
                            val csvData = convertLogsToCSV(logs)
                            val csvFile = context?.let { createCSVFile(csvData, it) }
                            Timber.tag("TEST").d("email %s", model.getDeviceLogs())
                            val to = "goodnature@notARealEmail.co.nz"
                            val subject = "test"
                            val body = "test body"
                            val intent = Intent(Intent.ACTION_SEND).apply {
                                data = Uri.parse("mailto:")
                                putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_EMAIL, arrayOf(to))
                                putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_SUBJECT, subject)
                                putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_TEXT, body)
                                putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_STREAM, Uri.fromFile(csvFile))
                            }
                            startActivity(intent)
                        }
                    )

When I run this code, the attatchment doesn't go in the email because "gmail lacks permissions" what should I be doing instead?

name: Coding Sensei
mes:
Based on your code snippet, it looks like you need to add permissions to grant Gmail access to the file you're attaching. Here's a modified version of your code that should help:

```kotlin
TrapScreen(
    viewModel = model,
    onBack = { findNavController().navigateUp() },
    sendEmail = {
        val logs = model.getDeviceLogs()
        val csvData = convertLogsToCSV(logs)
        val csvFile = context?.let { createCSVFile(csvData, it) }
        Timber.tag("TEST").d("email %s", model.getDeviceLogs())
        val to = "goodnature@notARealEmail.co.nz"
        val subject = "test"
        val body = "test body"

        // Convert csvFile to Uri
        val fileUri = csvFile?.let { FileProvider.getUriForFile(context!!, context!!.applicationContext.packageName + ".provider", it) }

        val intent = Intent(Intent.ACTION_SEND).apply {
            type = "text/csv"
            data = Uri.parse("mailto:")
            putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_EMAIL, arrayOf(to))
            putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_SUBJECT, subject)
            putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_TEXT, body)
            fileUri?.let {
                putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_STREAM, it)
                // Grant permission
                addFlags(Intent.FLAG_GRANT_READ_URI_PERMISSION)
            }
        }
        if (intent.resolveActivity(context!!.packageManager) != null) {
            startActivity(intent)
        }
    }
)
```

In the modified code:
1. We create a `Uri` for the file using `FileProvider`.
2. We grant read permission by adding `Intent.FLAG_GRANT_READ_URI_PERMISSION`.

Additionally, make sure you have a `FileProvider` configured in your `AndroidManifest.xml`:

```xml
<application>
    ...
    <provider
        android:name="androidx.core.content.FileProvider"
        android:authorities="${applicationId}.provider"
        android:exported="false"
        android:grantUriPermissions="true">
        <meta-data
            android:name="android.support.FILE_PROVIDER_PATHS"
            android:resource="@xml/file_paths" />
    </provider>
    ...
</application>
```

And define the paths in a `res/xml/file_paths.xml` file:

```xml
<paths xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android">
    <files-path name="csv" path="." />
</paths>
```

By ensuring that the `Uri` has the appropriate permissions and utilizing `FileProvider`, your attachment should be accessible by Gmail.
swipes:
"It seems like you're having a permission issue with the attachment when trying to send an email using Gmail. You need to request the necessary permissions to read and write to external storage in your AndroidManifest.xml if you haven't already done so:

```xml
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE"/>
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE"/>
```

And make sure you request these permissions at runtime for Android 6.0 (API level 23) and above. Here is an example of how you can request these permissions:

```java
private void requestStoragePermissions() {
    if (ContextCompat.checkSelfPermission(this, Manifest.permission.WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE)
        != PackageManager.PERMISSION_GRANTED) {
        ActivityCompat.requestPermissions(this, new String[]{Manifest.permission.WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE}, 1000);
    }
}
```

Another thing you have to make sure is that your file is accessible by other apps. You can achieve this by adding a `FileProvider` in your AndroidManifest.xml:

```xml
<provider
    android:name="androidx.core.content.FileProvider"
    android:authorities="${applicationId}.fileprovider"
    android:exported="false"
    android:grantUriPermissions="true">
    <meta-data
        android:name="android.support.FILE_PROVIDER_PATHS"
        android:resource="@xml/provider_paths" />
</provider>
```

And create a `provider_paths.xml` in your `res/xml` directory:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<paths xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android">
    <external-path name="external_files" path="."/>
</paths>
```

When you're creating the intent, use the `FileProvider.getUriForFile()` method to get the URI for your file. Also, add `FLAG_GRANT_READ_URI_PERMISSION` to your intent:

```java
val uri = csvFile?.let { FileProvider.getUriForFile(context, "${context.packageName}.fileprovider", it) }
val intent = Intent(Intent.ACTION_SEND).apply {
    data = Uri.parse("mailto:")
    putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_EMAIL, arrayOf(to))
    putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_SUBJECT, subject)
    putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_TEXT, body)
    putExtra(Intent.EXTRA_STREAM, uri)
    addFlags(Intent.FLAG_GRANT_READ_URI_PERMISSION)
}
startActivity(intent)
```

This should resolve the permission issue you're encountering.
